Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

Clariant is committed to operating and maintaining our processes in a safe and responsible manner.  We are dedicated to protecting the health and safety of our employees and neighbors as well as the environment at our site and in our community.  Our goal is always zero incidents.

We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances:

The Clariant Louisville West Plant manufactures customized precipitated catalysts and catalyst

carriers. They are used in various industries to aid in the manufacture of other products.  They set in motion a desired chemical reaction or process using much less energy than otherwise needed and minimizes the output of waste and greenhouse gases.  This Risk Management Plan (RMP) covers the use of titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4), a chemical regulated by the EPA. Titanium tetrachloride is used by plastic resin manufacturers to more efficiently make polypropylene which is used to makes plastics that go into many useful consumer products, including car bumpers, bicycles, medical devices and toys.  The process is comprised of interconnected units including the tank farm and production process.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

Clariant takes a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous

chemicals.  We used multiple layers of protection to avoid hazards, with each layer adding additional layers of safety.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful process safety programs including:

Employee participation: Employees are highly trained.  Control room operators constantly monitor the systems and respond quickly.

Process safety information: Complete and accurate informatio

n on the process technology, equipment and hazardous/physical characteristics of the chemical are maintained.

Operating procedures: Written operating procedures address all steps for each operation to assure understanding and compliance.

Training: All employees are trained for their specific jobs with an emphasis on safety and health hazards, emergency operations and safe work practices.

Mechanical integrity: Written procedures cover assuring the integrity of equipment and instruments throughout the plant.

Management of change:This system ensures that any changes to facilities, process chemicals, technologies, equipment, procedures or administrative controls take into consideration the impact of the change on safety.

Pre-startup review: All processes are reviewed and safety considerations addressed to assure it is safe to start up the process.

Process hazard analysis: An analysis of covered processes, conducted every five years, is a detailed study used to identify potential hazards and the measures needed to ensure the hazards are controlled.

Incident investigation: If an incident occurs, it will be thoroughly investigated and causes determined, corrective actions identified and implemented, and employees trained in the new actions.

Hot work permit/ Safe work practices: We strictly adhere to internal permitting processes to prevent accidents during performance of hot work, confined space entry, working in elevated altitude; our employees are trained to assure they fully understand these processes.

Contractor safety: Contractors are carefully chosen for their safety performance and are expected to maintain the same safety procedures as employees.

Emergency Planning & Response: Plant emergency responders can take actions should an incident occur.  The plant also works closely with local responders to assure they are aware of our operations and are able to assist should the need arise.

Compliance Audits: Every three years, compliance audits are conducted to

verify that the prevention program is adequate and being followed.

These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to maintaining these management systems and recognize that this is the way we do business.  We have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention. 



Five Year Accident History:

The Clariant Louisville West Plant is introducing titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4) for the first time and, therefore, has not had an accidental release of titanium tetrachloride in the past five years.



Emergency Response Program:

Clariant maintains an emergency response plan which addresses all of the various federal, state,

and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provides the

essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment

during emergency situations. Our plan also includes specific procedures for responding to a release of titanium tetrachloride, our only RMP chemical on site.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

At Clariant, we are committed to continuous improvement of environment, health, and safety

performance. Through our Process Safety Management program, we review hazards associated

with our processes and implement actions to reduce the hazards according to risk assessment/risk management principles.



Clariant is dedicated to protecting the health and safety of our employees and neighbors as well as the environment at our site and in our community. Our goal is always zero incidents.
